value:
<add xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" place="margin">
            <l>And Anon the</l>
            <l>dramatist also</l>
            <l>speaks himself. For</l>
            <l>the audience <del>requires</del></l>
            <l>[feels?] still part of the</l>
            <l>play, insists on</l>
            <l>repetition: it must</l>
            <l>be [adu?] to sit, a shad</l>
            <l>[thorn?], have a</l>
            <l>story: & as poetry is</l>
            <l>told in poetry, it</l>
            <l>must have action:</l>
            <l>[suicide?]: adultery.</l>
            <l>The anticipation of the</l>
            <l>audience to the</l>
            <l>
              <choice>
                <sic>Et<hi rend="superscript">hn</hi></sic>
                <corr>Elizabethan</corr>
              </choice> play was</l>
            <l>[unfortunate?]. The</l>
            <l>words will not</l>
            <l>fit the speakers:</l>
            <l>the [illeg.], the</l>
            <l><del>[lapne?]</del> confusion:</l>
            <l>no one feels what</l>
            <l>they say, the</l>
            <l>emotion is often</l>
            <l>plastered onto a</l>
            <l>inappropriate figures.</l>
            <l>But if one must</l>
            <l>have violence, how</l>
            <l>avoid this</l>
            <l>[illeg.]</l>
          </add>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">at a distance from the moment. Nobody cares what</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">his own private experience is. And so the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">songs of <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs> repeat over & over again what</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>that</del> Gather ye flowers while ye may; Death is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">coming: Anon is never tired of celebrating</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the Rose; <del>never</del> & that his [illeg.] is white;</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he is a repetitious, <del>co</del> And since he is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">content to <del>say</del> go unnoted, we cannot</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">pin him down, we cannot</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">separate him from his song. He has</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">thus an anonymous vitality, drawn from</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">other bodies, a perennial, common vigour.</l>

<del xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <l>Nor is he dead in ourselves. The crude early</l>
            <l>dramas still persuade us to read – not to</l>
            <l><del>find</del> for the story. What comes next?</l>
            <l>The <del>fil</del> <del>dramatist</del> Anon has little</l>
          </del>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>care for the</del> <del>[Abound?]</del> So we become</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">anonymous, in the early literature.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It is only later, when the pressure of emotion had</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>ca</del> strewn up words, as <del>a</del> the fingers of a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the man at the <rs type="object" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#obj-mono" key="Monotype">monotype machine</rs> cast</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">letters out of the bubbling metal, that</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">we lose this quality, to gain ––?––</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">everything it seems. For <del>there</del> <del>flocking</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the curtain [gives?] on rising. And now it has</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">risen on <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-hen5" key="Henry V">Henry the 5th</rs>; then on <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-mids" key="Midsummer Night's Dream, A">Midsummer Night</rs>:</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">on <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-rome" key="Romeo and Juliet">Romeo & Juliet</rs>; on <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-haml" key="Hamlet">Hamlet</rs> & <del><rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-ancl" key="Antony and Cleopatra">Cleo</rs></del> <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-temp" key="Tempest, The">The Tempest</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">By that time, there is nothing <del>left</del> unsaid:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the <del>whole of</del> <del>this</del> <del>to test</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The play has killed the stage. The stage has</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">become too small to act this drama.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Perhaps after centuries, the play will</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">renew itself, with Mozart in the <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-magi" key="Magic Flute, The">Magic Flute</rs>,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">as with <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-lbve">Beethoven</rs> in <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-fide" key="Fidelio">       .</rs>. It never</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">lived again in England. The book, after that, takes <add place="below">the place of the play</add></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">& <del>the</del> <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs> is dead for ever.</l>
